acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 3 from 72 hours ErC50=29mg/L of the algae (Scenedesmus) (CERI/NITE Hazard Assessment Report (preliminary version), 2006).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (dermal route) value of 610mg/kg (CERI Hazard Data 2001-4 (2002)) and rabbit LD50 value of 2,620mg/kg (DFGOT vol.4 (1992)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists
acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Because the rat LC50 (4-hour inhalation) value of 38ppm (0.16mg/L when the conversion factor of 1ppm = 4.08mg/m3 was applied) (CERI Hazard Data 2001-4 (2002)) exceeded the saturated vapour concentration (0.069ppm) under a saturated vapour pressure of 0.007Pa (20degC), the substance was considered as "dust exposure" and was classified into Category 2.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the LD50 value of 555mg/kg, calculated from the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 850mg/kg (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), 235mg/kg (female) , 400mg/kg, 409mg/kg (male), 495mg/kg, 824mg/kg, 840mg/kg, 900mg/kg, 1,100mg/kg and >1,050mg/kg (DFGOT vol.4 (1992)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category A4 by ACGIH (2001).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since there was rapidly degrading (the decomposition by TOC: 85%(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)) and the bio-accumulation was low (log Kow=1.62(PHYSPROP Database, 2005)), it was claasified into Not classified.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Cannot be classified due to lack of data.  Classified into "Corrosive Substances" by the UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods. However, the category includes skin corrosivity, and it is unclear whether the substance is classified as "metal" corrosive (UN#2215 (solid), UN#2215 (molten)).

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale:
Classified as "flammable" by ICSC (2004).
Classified into Class 8 (UN#2215 (solid), UN#2215 (molten)) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests and germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo, and negative data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (chromosome aberration tests), described in CERI Hazard Data 2001-4 (2002), ACGIH (7th, 2001), DFGOT vol.4 (1992) and NTP DB (Access on Mar., 2006).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Organic compounds containing oxygen (but not fluorine and chlorine), with the oxygen bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements)

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Not pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures: the auto-ignition temperature is 477degC (ICSC, 2004).

reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on no evidence of adverse effects on reproduction and development up to dose levels producing parental toxicity, described in CERI Hazard Data 2001-4 (2002), ACGIH (7th, 2001) and DFGOT vol.4 (1992).

respiratory_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause allergy or asthma symptoms or breathing difficulties if inhaled
respiratory_sensitizer.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is reported as a "Respiratory sensitization Substance" by the ad hoc committee of the Japanese Society of Occupational Allergy (2004).

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available (melting point: 53degC (ICSC, 2004), test temperature: 140degC).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing unsaturated bonds, with decomposition heat of 0.92kJ/g at temperatures in the range of 260 to 370degC according to Bretherick (J) (5th,1998). Classified into Division 6.1 and Class 8 (UN#2215 (solid), UN#2215 (molten)) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the descriptions in the reports on rabbit eye irritation tests : "severe irritation, and occasionally, irreversible damage were observed" (DFGOT vol.4 (1992)); "severe and permanent congestion and corneal vascularization were found" (ACGIH (7th, 2001)).

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (DFGOT Vol.4 (1992)): "application of wet powder with water caused necrosis" (though the results are not those of 4-hour application). The substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety if further subclassification is needed.

skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
skin_sensitizer.rationale: Based on the description in the report on Maximization tests on guinea pigs (CERI Hazard Data 2001-4 (2002)): "sensitization: positive." Also due to the fact that the substance is reported as a "Skin Sensitizing Substance" by the ad hoc committee of the Japanese Society of Occupational Allergy (2004).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification:
Category 1 (respiratory system, blood system),
Category 2 (kidney, liver, spleen)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement:
Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (respiratory system, blood system)
May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (kidney, liver, spleen)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale:
Based on the human evidence: "In one case, a worker who was occupationally exposed to maleic anhydride exhibited pulmonary edema," "irritation of the upper respiratory tract" (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), "stridor and short of breath," "coughing, irritation/burning sensation in the pharynx, photosensitivity and asthma" (CERI Hazard Data 2001-4 (2002)), "asthma and hemolytic anemia" (DFGOT vol.11 (1998)), and the evidence from animal studies including "inflammation and hyperplasia of the nasal tissues" (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), "renal tubular dilatation and epithelial degeneration," "reduced RBC/ hematocrit levels," "alveolar hemorrhage" (CERI Hazard Data 2001-4 (2002)), "parenchymal atrophy of the liver/kidney/spleen" (HSDB (2005)), "adverse effects on the blood system" (IRIS (1988)). 
The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Categories 1 and 2. The effects on the kidneys, liver and spleen were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1. However, these effects are classified into Category 2 since the priority rating of the referenced study (HSDB) is 2.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement:
Causes damage to organs (respiratory system, gastrointestinal tract)
May cause damage to organs (liver)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence: "In a case of inadvertent inhalation exposure, the patient exhibited burning sensation in the eye and throat, coughing, dyspnea and vomiting immediately after inhalation of fumes. Gasping and rale occurred next morning. The patient was diagnosed with bronchial asthma" (CERI Hazard Data 2001-4 (2002)). Also based on the evidence from animal studies: "some deaths from bronchial pneumonia were observed in inhalation studies" (CERI Hazard Data 2001-4 (2002)), "oral administration caused hemorrhage of the liver and lung," "inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract (dermal route)" (DFGOT vol.4 (1992)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Categories 1 and 2.
